result.markdown:
# Welch ANOVA for PCA cluster pairwise comparisons ## Overview Did some more reading on March 15, 2023 and decided a better way to deal with the issue of hetergeneous variance is to do Welch's ANOVA followed by Games-Howell pairwise comparisons. See Lakens et al. (2019) "Taking Parametric Assumptions Seriously: Arguments for the Use of Welch's F-test instead of the Classical F-test in One-Way ANOVA" for more info on Welch's F-test. See Sauder & Demars (2019) plus their supplemental material on OSF for more about the Games-Howell test In R, Wech's ANOVA can be accomplished with `oneway.test(…, var.equal = FALSE)` , or `{rstatix}` has a wrapper function `welch_anova_test()`. For Games-Howell, `{rstatix}` has `games_howell_test()` [documentation here](https://search.r-project.org/CRAN/refmans/rstatix/html/games_howell_test.html). From the documentation (emphasis added): > Performs Games-Howell test, which is used to compare all possible combinations of group differences when the assumption of homogeneity of variances is violated. > This post hoc test provides confidence intervals for the differences between group means and shows whether the differences are statistically significant. > > The test is based on Welch's degrees of freedom correction and uses Tukey's studentized range distribution for computing the p-values. > The test compares the difference between each pair of means with **appropriate adjustment for the multiple testing**. > So there is **no need to apply additional p-value corrections**. ::: {.cell} ::: ## Validation points per cluster Here I am illustrating how many independent validation points we have for each cluster assignment, for the different model options from k = 4, 6, 8. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: Note that clusters with only 1 member won't be included in pairwise comparison b/c not possible to calculate variance with only 1 member... ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Soil properties for pairwise comparisons Because our validation data points are coming from different projects / datasets, we don't have exactly the same variables from each project. This is a reminder of which variables exist in the three sources we used for validation points: - KSSL : clay, bulk density, lep, awc, ec, cec, pH, carbonates, organic matter, (est org C) - CIG: clay, bulk density, pH, carbonates, organic matter, (est org C) - SHI: clay, bulk density, pH, organic matter In summary: all three datasets include bulk density, pH, organic matter, and clay, and KSSL and CIG include carbonates. So I think it makes sense to focus on plotting and doing pairwise comparisons with these variables specifically ## Example pairwise: OM, k=6 Working out the steps I need to include in a function to do the pairwise comparisons. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # test case k=6 version and organic matter test_dat <- val_dat %>% select(val_unit_id, k_6, om_loi, claytotal, source) %>% drop_na(om_loi) # note only 1 observation for clust_1, need to drop it # b/c can't calculate variance for the pairwise comparison w/ only 1 obs. test_dat %>% count(k_6) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} test_dat_mult <- test_dat %>% filter(k_6 != "clust_1") # plot to see distributions test_dat_mult %>% ggplot(aes(x = k_6, y = om_loi)) + geom_boxplot() + geom_point() + theme_bw() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} test_lm <- lm(formula = om_loi ~ k_6, data = test_dat_mult) # look at some diagnostic plots for our model # note homogeneity of variance looks sketchy performance::check_model(test_lm, check = c("normality", "homogeneity", "linearity")) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-4-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # runs Bartlett Test for homogeneity of variance performance::check_homogeneity(test_lm) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Warning: Variances differ between groups (Bartlett Test, p = 0.000). ``` ::: ::: This shows how I would do Games-Howell pairwise comparisons ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} gh_om <- games_howell_test(formula = om_loi ~ k_6, data = test_dat_mult) gh_om ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # now we add a column "comparison" needed in order for # biostat::cld to make our "compact letter display" (letters # showing where we can/can't reject null that means are the same) # pairwise comps w/ Dunn's test gh_comp <- gh_om %>% mutate(comparison = glue("{group1}-{group2}")) biostat::make_cld(p.adj ~ comparison, data = gh_comp) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## Function to plot model checks I want to make some plots to check the assumptions of normally distributed residuals and homogeneity of variance. In chapter 27, where I show the non-parametric pairwise tests, I also have a section for running Levene's test to check homogeneity of variance. However, since Welch's ANOVA and Games-Howell make no assumptions about homogeneity variance, I'm not worried about running Levene's test here. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # working with these variables for the model checks # independent: k= 4, 6, 8 # dependent: vars = om_loi, dbthirdbar, ph1to1h2o, caco3, claytotal check_plots_anova <- function(soil_var, k_opt, df, log_trans_adj = FALSE) { dat_no_na <- df %>% select(val_unit_id, all_of(k_opt), all_of(soil_var)) %>% drop_na(all_of(soil_var)) # checking if any clusters are represented by 1 or less data points. Want to drop these n_obs_per_cluster <- dat_no_na %>% count(.data[[k_opt]]) single_obs_clusters <- n_obs_per_cluster %>% filter(n <= 1) %>% pull(.data[[k_opt]]) if (length(single_obs_clusters) == 0) { dat_subset <- dat_no_na } else{ dat_subset <- dat_no_na %>% filter(!(.data[[k_opt]] %in% single_obs_clusters)) } if(log_trans_adj){ # note this is for CaCO3, need to add 1 to avoid # zero values f <- paste0("log10(", soil_var, "+1)~", k_opt) }else{ f <- paste0(soil_var, " ~ ", k_opt) } mod <- lm(formula = f, data = dat_subset) check_plots <- performance::check_model(mod, check = c("normality", "homogeneity", "linearity")) return(list(var = glue("{soil_var}"), plots = check_plots)) } ``` ::: ## k=4 model checks ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "claytotal", k_opt = "k_4", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var claytotal $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "ph1to1h2o", k_opt = "k_4", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var ph1to1h2o $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "dbthirdbar", k_opt = "k_4", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var dbthirdbar $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-3.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "om_loi", k_opt = "k_4", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var om_loi $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-4.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # note we need to log10 transform here (+1) to meet the assumption of normally distributed residuals check_plots_anova(soil_var = "caco3", k_opt = "k_4", df = val_dat, log_trans_adj = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var caco3 $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-7-5.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## k=6 model checks ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "claytotal", k_opt = "k_6", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var claytotal $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "ph1to1h2o", k_opt = "k_6", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var ph1to1h2o $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "dbthirdbar", k_opt = "k_6", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var dbthirdbar $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-3.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "om_loi", k_opt = "k_6", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var om_loi $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-4.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "caco3", k_opt = "k_6", df = val_dat, log_trans_adj = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var caco3 $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-5.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## k=8 model checks ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "claytotal", k_opt = "k_8", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var claytotal $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "ph1to1h2o", k_opt = "k_8", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var ph1to1h2o $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "dbthirdbar", k_opt = "k_8", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var dbthirdbar $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-3.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "om_loi", k_opt = "k_8", df = val_dat) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var om_loi $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-4.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} check_plots_anova(soil_var = "caco3", k_opt = "k_8", df = val_dat, log_trans_adj = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $var caco3 $plots ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-5.png){width=672} ::: ::: ## Function for Games-Howell pairwise comparisons Arguments: soil property and k option (model version / number of clusters) and validation dataframe. Returns: all pairwise comparisons in a dataframe ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} compare_clust_pairwise <- function(soil_var, k_opt, df = val_dat) { ### prep data dat_no_na <- df %>% select(val_unit_id, all_of(k_opt), all_of(soil_var)) %>% drop_na(all_of(soil_var)) # can't do pairwise t-tests with only 1 obs in a # group, so need to filter those out n_obs_per_cluster <- dat_no_na %>% count(.data[[k_opt]]) single_obs_clusters <- n_obs_per_cluster %>% filter(n <= 1) %>% pull(.data[[k_opt]]) if (length(single_obs_clusters) == 0) { dat_subset <- dat_no_na } else{ dat_subset <- dat_no_na %>% filter(!(.data[[k_opt]] %in% single_obs_clusters)) } ### perform pairwise comparison f <- as.formula(paste0(soil_var, " ~ ", k_opt)) pairs_df <- games_howell_test(data = dat_subset, formula = f) %>% mutate(comparison = glue("{group1} - {group2}")) cld_df <- biostat::make_cld(p.adj ~ comparison, data = pairs_df) ### results results_list <- list(pairs_df = pairs_df, cld = cld_df) return(results_list) } ``` ::: ## Example function output This is what the pairwise function I wrote above returns: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} ph_test <- compare_clust_pairwise(soil_var = "ph1to1h2o", k_opt = "k_8", df = val_dat) ph_test ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` $pairs_df # A tibble: 21 × 9 .y. group1 group2 estimate conf.low conf.high p.adj p.adj.signif 1 ph1to1h2o clust_1 clust_2 -0.119 -1.66 1.42 1 e+ 0 ns 2 ph1to1h2o clust_1 clust_3 0.00222 -1.50 1.50 1 e+ 0 ns 3 ph1to1h2o clust_1 clust_4 1.16 -0.399 2.71 1.32e- 1 ns 4 ph1to1h2o clust_1 clust_5 0.566 -0.926 2.06 6.68e- 1 ns 5 ph1to1h2o clust_1 clust_6 1.39 -0.165 2.94 7.4 e- 2 ns 6 ph1to1h2o clust_1 clust_7 0.625 -0.865 2.12 5.87e- 1 ns 7 ph1to1h2o clust_2 clust_3 0.122 -0.451 0.694 9.81e- 1 ns 8 ph1to1h2o clust_2 clust_4 1.28 0.953 1.60 0 **** 9 ph1to1h2o clust_2 clust_5 0.685 0.220 1.15 6.27e- 4 *** 10 ph1to1h2o clust_2 clust_6 1.51 1.18 1.84 9.92e-13 **** # ℹ 11 more rows # ℹ 1 more variable: comparison $cld group cld spaced_cld 1 clust_1 abc abc 2 clust_2 a a__ 3 clust_3 ab ab_ 4 clust_4 c __c 5 clust_5 b _b_ 6 clust_6 c __c 7 clust_7 b _b_ ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} comps <- ph_test[["pairs_df"]] comps %>% select(group1, group2, p.adj) %>% filter(p.adj < 0.05) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ## Run pairwise comparisons Here I create a dataframe to hold the results of the pairwise comparisons, then use `map2()` to iterate over the variables and cluster sizes, running all the tests. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # transform CaCO3 in the dataframe beforehand val_dat_trans <- val_dat %>% mutate(caco3 = log10(caco3+1)) # dependent vars soil_var <- c("claytotal", "ph1to1h2o", "om_loi", "caco3", "dbthirdbar") # independent vars all possible values of k (number of clusters) k_opt <- as.character(glue("k_{c(4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11)}")) # create df with all combinations of var_names x clusters mod_template <- tidyr::crossing(soil_var, k_opt) ``` ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # run the pairwise comparisons for each var and cluster size diffs_df <- mod_template %>% mutate(comps_all = map2( .x = soil_var, .y = k_opt, .f = compare_clust_pairwise )) # unnest once to get the pairs_df and cld_df dfs # as their own columns diffs_unnest <- diffs_df %>% unnest(comps_all) %>% mutate(obj_names = names(comps_all)) # want to save pairs_df and cld_df dat separately, so filtering # and then unnesting again to get rectangular data pairs_dat <- diffs_unnest %>% filter(obj_names == "pairs_df") %>% unnest(comps_all) %>% select(-obj_names) write_csv(pairs_dat, "data/pca_welch_pairwise_results_all.csv") cld_dat <- diffs_unnest %>% filter(obj_names == "cld") %>% unnest(comps_all) %>% select(-obj_names) write_csv(cld_dat, "data/cld_display_welch.csv") ``` ::: Now need to count how many of the tests have an adjusted p-value \< 0.05. All of the p-values are already adjusted (see documentation for `games_howell_test()` ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} count_sig_comps <- function(df){ df %>% filter(p.adj<0.05) %>% nrow() } sig_diffs_df <- pairs_dat %>% select(k_opt, soil_var, group1, group2, p.adj) %>% group_by(k_opt, soil_var) %>% nest(data = c(group1, group2, p.adj)) %>% mutate(n_sig_comps = map_int(data, count_sig_comps)) %>% mutate( num_regions = as.numeric(str_extract(k_opt, "[:digit:]+")), possible_comps = (num_regions * (num_regions - 1)) / 2, alpha_comps = round(possible_comps * 0.05, digits = 0) ) %>% select(soil_var, k_opt, num_regions, data, n_sig_comps, possible_comps, alpha_comps) sig_diffs_summary <- sig_diffs_df %>% select(soil_var, k_opt, num_regions, n_sig_comps, possible_comps, alpha_comps) write_csv(sig_diffs_summary, "data/pca_welch_pairwise_comparisons_summary.csv") ``` ::: ## Plot comparisons ### All clusters ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: For context, this plot shows a black line for the total number of **possible** contrasts. Note that because we are showing each soil property variable separately, the "total possible" line illustrates the total number of possible comparisons for a single variable ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: Two other ways to contextualize the number of significant contrasts: 1) with a table, and 2) with a plot showing how the % significant contrasts (as a function of total possible) changes as the number of clusters goes up. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](29-welch-pairwise_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){width=672} ::: :::
